t: Isaiah 29
Woe to Jerusalem
Woe*pn to Ariel, Ariel, the*ln city where David camped! Continue*ln year after year; let*ln the festivals recur.
I*ln will oppress Ariel, and*ln there will be mourning and crying, and*ln she will be to me like an Ariel.
I*ln will camp in a circle around you; I*ln will besiege you with earth ramps, and*ln I will set up my siege towers against you.

You*ln will be brought down; you*ln will speak from the ground, and*ln your words will come from low in the dust. Your*ln voice will be like that of a spirit from the ground; your*ln speech will whisper from the dust.
Your*pn many foes will be like fine dust, and*ln many of the ruthless, like blowing chaff. Then*ln suddenly, in an instant,
you*ln will be punished by the Lord*s of Armies with*ln thunder, earthquake, and loud noise, storm,*ln tempest, and a flame of consuming fire.
All*ln the many nations going*ln out to battle against Ariel — all*ln the attackers, the siege works against her, and*ln those who oppress her — will*ln then be like a dream, a vision in the night.

It*ln will be like a hungry one who dreams he is eating, then*ln wakes and is still hungry; and*ln like a thirsty one who dreams he is drinking, then*ln wakes and is still thirsty, longing for water. So*ln it will be for all the many nations who*ln go to battle against Mount Zion.
Stop*pn and be astonished; blind*ln yourselves and be blind! They*ln are drunk, but not with wine; they*ln stagger, but not with beer.
For*ln the Lord*s has poured out on you an*ln overwhelming urge to sleep; he*ln has shut your eyes (the prophets) and*ln covered your heads (the seers).
For*p you the entire vision will be like the words of a sealed document. If it is given to one who can read and he is asked to read it, he will say, “I can’t read it, because it is sealed.”
And if the document is given to one who cannot read and he is asked to read it, he will say, “I can’t read.”
The*p Lord said: These*pn people approach me with their speeches to*ln honor me with lip-service, yet*ln their hearts are far from me, and*ln human rules direct their worship of me.
Therefore,*ln I will again confound these people with*ln wonder after wonder. The*ln wisdom of their wise will vanish, and*ln the perception of their perceptive will be hidden.
Woe*pn to those who go to great lengths to*ln hide their plans from the Lord.*s They*ln do their works in the dark, and*ln say, “Who sees us? Who knows us?”

You*ln have turned things around, as*ln if the potter were the same as the clay. How*ln can what is made say about its maker, “He*ln didn’t make me”? How*ln can what is formed say*ln about the one who formed it, “He*ln doesn’t understand what he’s doing”?
Isn’t*pn it true that in just a little while Lebanon*ln will become an orchard, and*ln the orchard will seem like a forest?
On*ln that day the deaf will hear the*ln words of a document, and*ln out of a deep darkness the*ln eyes of the blind will see.
The*ln humble will have joy after*ln joy in the Lord,*s and*ln the poor people will rejoice in*ln the Holy One of Israel.
For*ln the ruthless one will vanish, the*ln scorner will disappear, and*ln all those who lie in wait with evil intent will*ln be killed —
those*ln who, with their speech, accuse*ln a person of wrongdoing, who*ln set a trap for the one mediating at the city gate and*ln without cause deprive the righteous of justice.
Therefore,*p the Lord*s who redeemed Abraham says this about the house of Jacob: Jacob*pn will no longer be ashamed, and*ln his face will no longer be pale.
For*ln when he sees his children, the*ln work of my hands within his nation, they*ln will honor my name, they*ln will honor the Holy One of Jacob and*ln stand in awe of the God of Israel.
Those*ln who are confused will gain understanding, and*ln those who grumble will accept instruction.
